metadata.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellant joined railway service in August 1924 as a Signaller Telegraphist.
Appellant promoted as Section Controller in 1942, Deputy Chief Controller in 1947, Chief Controller in 1950, all in Class III service.

On March 31, 1951, appellant appeared before selection board for post of Assistant Superintendent Railway Telegraphs, gazetted post in Class II Officers cadre, and was selected out of seven candidates.

Notice of appointment issued on July 2, 1951, appointing Mr. Parshotam Lal, Officiating Chief Controller, to officiate in Class II service as Asstt. Spdt. Rly. Telegraphs, Headquarters Office vice Mr. Sahu Ram.
Appellant relieved Mr. Sahu Ram and actually joined in the afternoon of July 3, 1951.
On April 28, 1953, Gouri Shankar S.T.E.I. Hd. Qrs. made adverse remarks against appellant in confidential report for year ending March 31, 1953.
Confidential report came before Shri Sen, C.S.T.E., on May 25, 1953, who confirmed adverse views and added his own adverse opinion.

On June 11, 1953, General Manager Shri Karnail Singh remarked: 'I am disappointed to read these reports. He should revert as a subordinate till he makes good the short-comings noticed in this chance of his as an officer.'

Adverse remarks communicated to appellant by confidential letter No. E-106/180 dated June 29, 1953: 'He is, however, inclined to be hasty in his decisions. His office work is scrappy... without any improvement.' Plus remarks of Sen and GM.
Appellant made representation against remarks on July 24, 1953, after earning two increments on July 4, 1952 and July 4, 1953.

On August 19, 1953, notice No. 940-E/14 E.I.A. issued by General Manager: Shri Bishambar Nath Chopra transferred to officiate as Assistant Signal and Tele-communication Engineer Telegraphs vice Shri Parshotam Lal Dhingra, who on relief reverts to Class III appointment.
Appellant appealed to General Manager on August 20, 1953, then to Railway Board on October 19, 1953, and represented to President of India.
Railway Board wrote to General Manager on February 2, 1955: Reversion stands for unsatisfactory work, not bar to future promotion if improved; language in representation unbecoming.
Petitioner filed writ petition under Art. 226 on February 9, 1955.
Mr. Justice Harnam Singh allowed writ on April 15, 1955, set aside reversion order as violation of Art. 311(2).
Division Bench (Bhandari C.J. and Falshaw J.) reversed on January 19, 1956, dismissed writ.
Punjab High Court granted certificate of fitness on August 20, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order passed by the General Manager on August 19, 1953, reverting the petitioner from officiating Class II post to substantive Class III post amounted to a reduction in rank within the meaning of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Petitioner had been punished by being reduced in rank without opportunity to show cause against proposed action, violating Art. 311(2).

respondent_arguments.text: Reversion was not a reduction in rank by way of punishment but termination of officiating appointment; no right to post acquired; Art. 311(2) not attracted.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Articles 310 and 311; service rules; officiating nature of appointment

court_reasoning.text: Art. 310 adopts pleasure doctrine subject to Art. 311 protections against dismissal/removal by subordinate authority and without opportunity for dismissal/removal/reduction in rank.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art. 311 applies to all government servants, permanent or temporary/officiating.

court_reasoning.text: Dismissal, removal, reduction in rank in Art. 311 denote major punishments under service rules requiring procedure; termination under contract/rules not punishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test: whether servant had right to post/rank, or visited with penal consequences beyond normal termination.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant appointed to officiate in Class II post (no substantive right); reversion to substantive Class III not forfeiture of right, no penal consequences (no loss of seniority/promotion chances); not punishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reversion order did not entail forfeiture of pay/allowances/seniority or bar future promotion.

holdings.text: Order of reversion from officiating higher post to substantive lower post is not reduction in rank by way of punishment under Art. 311(2) where no right to higher post and no penal consequences.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Abdul Majid
precedents_cited.relevance: Indian law did not adopt English Common Law pleasure doctrine in entirety.
English Common Law: servants hold during Crown's pleasure.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lucas v. Lucas and High Commissioner for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied English pleasure doctrine to Indian Civil Servant.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. Venkata Rao v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Rules under 1915 Act regulate but do not create enforceable rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. A. Venkataraman v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Arts. 310-311 fetter pleasure to impose procedure for punishments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satish Chander Anand v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Contractual termination not dismissal/removal under Art. 311.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Compulsory retirement under rules not punishment under Art. 311(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Jayanti Prasad v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Termination not by way of punishment does not attract Art. 311(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Laxminarayan Chiranjilal Bhargava v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Held temporary servants not entitled to Art. 311; court rejects distinction.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Pleasure doctrine qualified by protections against arbitrary dismissal/removal/reduction; applies to all civil servants.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Substantially reproduced in Arts. 310-311; introduced opportunity to show cause.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1919
statutes_cited.relevance: First statutory recognition of pleasure with qualifications.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1915
statutes_cited.relevance: Subject to rules; no enforceable rights.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railway Establishment Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines penalties; discharge of officiating not removal/dismissal/reduction.

statutes_cited.name: Civil Service (Classification, Control and Appeal) Rules, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: Major penalties include dismissal/removal/reduction; special procedure; explanations exclude probationary/officiating terminations.

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Quasi-permanent service protections; termination by notice.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines lien, officiating, permanent/temporary posts; pay ceases on dismissal/removal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Division Bench decision reversing Single Judge; held reversion from officiating Class II to substantive Class III not reduction in rank by way of punishment under Art. 311(2) as no right to higher post and no penal consequences; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "The real test for determining whether the termination of the service of a Government servant is by way of punishment is to ascertain whether the servant, but for such termination, had the right to hold the post."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the case satisfies either [test: right to post or penal consequences], then it must be held that the servant has been punished."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dual test for punishment: right or evil consequences.

key_quotes.text: "Art. 311 does not, in terms, say that the protections of that article extend only to persons who are permanent members of the services."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Art. 311 applies to all government servants, not just permanent.
